xyz.acygn.mokapot

Class DistributedCommunicator

  • java.lang.Object
    • xyz.acygn.mokapot.DistributedCommunicator

  • public class DistributedCommunicator
extends Object
    An object that handles communication to and from remote systems. At most one of these may be active at a time per JVM, and one must be active in order to be able to carry out distributed communications. As such, it's sensible to talk about "the distributed communicator" for a particular JVM.

    Starting up communications creates a listener that other systems can use to communicate with and run code on this system; this is a necessary part of running programs on more than one system. (That is, starting outbound communications starts inbound communications at the same time.)

    This class currently does no sandboxing of its own, so ensure that the port is correctly secured via other means, e.g. installing a restrictive security manager and firewalling the port. As a precaution, attempts to construct instances of the class will fail unless a security manager is installed.

    Author:
    Alex Smith

    • Constructor Detail

      • DistributedCommunicator

        public DistributedCommunicator(CommunicationAddress myAddress)
        Creates a new distributed communicator. The communicator will not start communicating immediately, and cannot be used until it is.

        When creating the communicator, it's necessary to specify an address. This will be used for two purposes: telling other systems how to connect to this system; and by the distributed communicator itself, to know what settings it should use for communications from outside. Thus, the address will be determined to some extent by the conditions of the local system (e.g. if TCP is being used for the communication, then the IP address contained within the communication address must actually refer to the local system). However, there may be more flexibility in other parts of the address (e.g. if TCP is being used for the communication, then any port that can receive messages from the other machines involved can be used as part of the address).

        Parameters:
        myAddress - The communication address via which other systems will contact this system.
        Throws:
        SecurityException - If there is no security manager installed.
        See Also:
        startCommunication()

    • Method Detail

      • getCommunicator

        public static DistributedCommunicator getCommunicator()
        Returns the active distributed communicator for this VM. Only one distributed communicator can be active on a particular JVM at any given time.
        Returns:
        This JVM's active distributed communicator, or null if there are no such communicators.

      • setDebugMonitor

        public void setDebugMonitor(DebugMonitor debugMonitor)
        Sets the debug monitor for this communicator. Installing a new debug monitor will replace the old one. In debug monitor mode, every message sent by or received by the communicator will call the debug monitor, with a human-readable string explaining the situation as argument.
        Parameters:
        debugMonitor - The new debug monitor. This can be null, in which case debug monitoring will be turned off.

      • startCommunication

        public void startCommunication()
                        throws IOException,
                               IllegalStateException
        Starts the communicator's ability to communicate. Until the communicator is told to stop communicating (and successfully shuts down), it will accept remote commands to run code, sent via the given port. Only one communicator per JVM may be communicating at any given time.

        Starting the communicator is also necessary before using it for outbound requests, to run code on other systems; this is because running code remotely may sometimes require some of the code to run on the local system (e.g. accesses to local objects), and thus the remote system will need to be able to run code here.

        Throws:
        IOException - If the operating system reported a failure to start listening for external connections
        IllegalStateException - If communications are already running

      • stopCommunication

        public void stopCommunication()
                       throws IllegalStateException
        Stops the communicator's ability to communicate.

        Will not return (or stop the communicator) until the communicator is idle. At present, this method does not do anything to try to make the communicator idle (e.g. migrating away objects, or refusing to accept new method calls). This may change in the future.

        Must only be called from a thread that is "outside" the communicator, i.e. has had no contact with it. (This may be a thread that was created by a method call via the communicator, so long as it was not created by the communicator itself, e.g. a Thread.start call via the communicator can create a thread to shut the communicator down.) Note that shutting down a communicator causes it to lose its identity; when restarted, it will be a fresh start, with no knowledge of its previous time running.

        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - If the communicator is already stopped, or already being stopped
        See Also:
        Thread.start()

      • getMyAddress

        public CommunicationAddress getMyAddress()
        Returns the communication address used by this distributed communicator. This address can be passed to another system involved in the distributed computation, to enable that system to send messages to this communicator.
        Returns:
        The communication address being used by this communicator,

      • runRemotely

        public <T> T runRemotely(CopiableSupplier<T> code,
                         CommunicationAddress onMachine)
        Runs the specified code on the specified machine, and returns its return value. The code may not throw checked exceptions, but may throw unchecked exceptions.

        Note that the object code that's used to specify the code must be effectively immutable, because the other machine will be working with a copy of the object (it couldn't work with the original, because then the code would have to run on the local machine, which defeats the point of running it remotely).

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the returned value.
        Parameters:
        code - The code to run.
        onMachine - The machine on which to run the function.
        Returns:
        The value supplied by the code being run, if any.

      • runRemotely

        public void runRemotely(CopiableRunnable code,
                        CommunicationAddress onMachine)
        An overloaded version of runRemotely(CopiableSupplier, CommunicationAddress). The given Runnable is converted to a Supplier that returns null, then the overloaded method is called with this Supplier.
        Parameters:
        code - The code to run.
        onMachine - The machine on which to run the function.
        See Also:
        runRemotely(CopiableSupplier, CommunicationAddress)

      • listAllRemotelyReferencedLocalObjects

        public Set<ObjectIdentity<?>> listAllRemotelyReferencedLocalObjects()
        Returns the set of all local objects that are long reference targets. Unless long references were created manually, this will be the set of local objects that are referenced from a remote system.

        The result will be instantaneously valid, but may immediately become outdated due to changes to long references made in different threads. As such, this should probably only be used for debugging purposes.

        TODO: This method currently does not return local objects that are implemented using inheritance-based standins. This is not an inherent limitation of the method (the information is available), but determining this information would be rather more complex than the current simple implementation can manage.

        Returns:
        A set of local objects that are long reference targets. (These are given as ObjectIdentity objects so that objects that are different but compare equal will not be removed from the set.)

      • listAllLocallyReferencedRemoteObjects

        public Set<ObjectIdentity<?>> listAllLocallyReferencedRemoteObjects()
        Returns the set of all remote objects that are the target of a long reference from this system. Note that the return values will also be (the object identities of) long references from this system to another, and thus will hold the remote objects in question alive.

        The result will be instantaneously valid, but may immediately become outdated due to changes to long references made in different threads. As such, this should probably only be used for debugging purposes.

        Returns:
        A set of long references to objects on other systems. (These are given as ObjectIdentity objects so that objects that are different but compare equal will not be removed from the set. Note that the long references created might be clones of the existing long references, and thus reference equality of the long references themselves might not hold true.)
